medicalConditions.conditionInfo: She suffers from Rheumatoid Arthritis. She has difficulty dressing herself due to arthritis in her hands or  obtaining comfortable shoes due to badly deformed toes. Because of her arthritis she needs assistance with toileting as she is unable to wipe herself effectively.

Louise has short term memory loss. Additionally she has delusional episodes where she is convinced that something bad has happened. Someone has died or intruders have entered the family home in Cyprus. She can get quite upset and needs reassurance and distraction. Following her assessment by the Memory clinic she has prescribed medication to keep her calm. This has helped. She does not wander about and is not otherwise at risk of harm to herself or anyone else.

appraisal2022.recipientLife: Louise is a Green Cypriot. She often refers to her life in Cyprus and has a strong desire to return to the family home there, although this is impractical now. She is a widow. She has 5 Children. in age order. Clea, who lives with her, Chris, who lives in Maidenhead. Maria who lives in Milton Keynes, Niki who lives in Orpington and William who lives 3 doors away at No 23 Ashleigh road. In addition Grace, her grandson (William's son) who lives a walking distance away.
appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow: Because of her dementia, she sometimes has delusions about certain events. For example, that someone close to her has died or that squatters have moved into the family home if it was left unattended. The best remedy is to offer to call the person whom she thinks has suffered harm. To reassure her that the house is safe and family members are looking after it or to distract. She often moves on and settles. The risperidone, administered at night helps to calm her. If she is very agitated over prolonged periods, it could be that she has contracted a urine infection.
appraisal2022.interestsInfo: She likes watching quiz shows on Tv and Music shows. She loves shows by Andrei Rue
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine: Louise get's up around 7;30-8:00am. She typically has breakfast, takes her medications and then gets showered and dressed. Her hair is washed ~3times a week.  She needs rich moisturising cream to be applied to her legs. After showring she typically watches TV. She falls asleep quite a lot during the day. She has lunch around 12:30pm and likes company whilst she is eating. Dinner is around 6pm. She has cups of tee in between meals with occasional biscuit or piece of cake, so as not to spoil her appetite. Louise goes to bed around 9:30-10:00Pm.
appraisal2022.continenceSupportOther: Louise suffers from deformed arthritic hands, which prevents her from being able to wipe herself or to wash her hands properly. She requires assistance from the carer to perform these tasks.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: She needs assistance with lowering onto and raising from the toilet seat due to arthritis in her knees, which restricts bending.
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo:
Whilst Louise can fall asleep for up to 2 hours, she cannot be left without frequent checks as she may struggle to getup to go to the toilet and have a fall. So the carer can do other tasks whilst Louise is asleep provided she is within reasonable proximity, earshot or can see her from a distance. At night we have a sensor on a matt by Louise's bed to alert the Carer if she is getting out of bed, so as to attend to her needs.
Note: To enable the Live-in carer to have a 2 hour break each day, we organised a local agency to provide a carer for 2 hours each day, 7 days a week. 14hours in total. Typically from 2-4pm.

adDescription:
Live-In Care Placement – Companion & Personal Support

We are seeking a kind, experienced female live-in carer to support an elderly lady whose needs are gradually increasing. She is becoming more confused and would benefit from consistent companionship and help with daily routines such as meals, personal care, and light household tasks.

This role offers the opportunity to provide one-to-one care in the comfort of the client’s own home, helping her remain independent while reducing isolation and promoting wellbeing. The placement will begin with a trial period, with ongoing support from Elder Care.

If you are compassionate, reliable, and experienced in live-in care, we would love to hear from you.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: Has had increased issues with memory over the last year - e.g. forgetting appointments, medication, bank details, names, finding using her computer and phone increasingly confusing.  Currently under assessment by NHS berkshire, confirmed diagnosis of altzheimer's on 27th jan 2025.

appraisal2022.recipientLife:
never been married, no kids.  career a mixture of voluntary, private and public sector work; prior to retirement was a practice manager for a GP practice in berkshire.  

family important and friends are important to her, although family don't live near her.  key people helping are

andrew inchley - nephew, and primary point for financial matters
david inchley - nephew, GP, and primary point for medical matters
rachel inchley
james spurrell
tony cowling - church leader and primary interlock with friends providing local support

has brother nick (and friend margaret) and sisters jane (and husband peter) and sally (and husband colin).

historically an active member of local church community; still regularly attends and has visitors / invitations to visit others.

some good friends further afield that she keeps in close contact with including mary seaton.
appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow:
has felt isolated in house (4 bed detached), exacerbated by memory issues; longer term expect to move.

recognises need for support given memory issues.  also looking for some companionship, but shouldn't be overbearing - she is still physically relatively healthy and doesn't want patronising... need to find the right balance of caring and giving her space in the house.

enjoys reading and gardening.
appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Active member of local church.  Currently in a 3 bed house on her own, although with regular visitors, primarily from church group.  No children or husband, but various nieces / nephews around the country who she regularly calls / sometimes has visit.  Plays piano.
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine: need to talk this through with lizzie.
appraisal2022.washingPreferenceOther: unknown - need to discuss with her.  my understanding is she is physically capable, but may need reminding.
appraisal2022.oralSupportOther: not sure as memory issue has progressed - somewhere between fully independent and requires prompting.
appraisal2022.dressingSupportOther: not sure as memory issue has progressed - somewhere between fully independent and requires prompting.

adDescription:
PART TIME PERMANENT PLACEMENT
START DATE: 17th Oct this is Part Time Perm Friday to Tuesday every week would like to same carer each week.
LOCATION: Oxted
NEAREST STATION: SurreyStation 0.5 miles

IMPORTANT INFORMATION: WE'RE LOOKING FOR A CARER WHO CAN CONTINUOUSLY PROVIDE CARE FROM FRIDAY TO TUESDAY AS PART OF A 4-DAY ASSIGNMENT.

CARE NEEDS: 
Herbert and Chris 88 yr old couple are seeking a compassionate and reliable carer to support them in their home. 

Herbert has dementia and can be confused and at times not very nice towards Chris. Herbert still wants to do things for herself and is still mobile and enjoys going for short walks, is showing increasing signs of confusion and can be unpredictable in her willingness to accept support. She enjoys music, often singing hymns, and maintains a good appetite. While Herbert feeds herself, she may occasionally take meals in bed and appreciates a calm, supportive presence during these times.

Although Herbert does not require personal care at this stage, she needs gentle supervision and prompting with daily routines. She is prone to night sweats and occasionally wakes during the night to make calls to local authorities, though she doesn’t require overnight assistance. She is sensitive to the cold and may choose to stay in bed longer some days. She is currently continent but may be nearing the stage of needing support in this area.

Medication is managed and administered by a nurse, so no medication handling is required. However, a carer should be observant and communicate any changes or concerns as needed.

Chris, her husband, is a proud and independent man who prepares all meals and manages household responsibilities. He uses a stair lift and is starting to find daily life more challenging. While he does not want personal care, he would benefit from an extra pair of hands around the home and a watchful eye to ensure both his and Herbert’s wellbeing.
NO PETS
WIFI - yes
BREAK GUARANTEED - yes
NO NIGHT SUPPORT NEEDED - could be occasionally 
LICENCE REQUIRED - NO
LOOKING FOR CARERS WHO CAN DO THE PLACEMENT ON A CONTINUOUS BASIS!!!

medicalConditions.conditionInfo:
Trelegy Ellipta: One puff daily; rinse mouth after use
Salamol 100mcg/dose inhaler: 1–2 puffs as needed, up to 4 times/day
Memantine 10mg tablets: One each morning
Levothyroxine sodium 75mcg tablets: One each morning, 30–60 mins before food or caffeine
Accrete D3 One a Day: One daily in the morning

Her partner Ron passed away 5 years ago, older son Alan died 7 years ago. Survivng son Graham lives in Australia. Edgar has 7 grandchildren (2- stephanie and Sam are in Australia). Closest is Tamsin who lives in Northwood hills with her partner Nick and three children Chloe, Eddie and Emery. Dean lives in Ickenham with his partner Busra, Luke and his family live in Luton, Leonard and his partner live in Scotland.
appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow: Edgar enjoys listening to the radio, listening to audio books and having time in the garden. She used to enjoy walking  but this would be limited to wheelchair use now as she gets easily puffed out. She and Ron owned a canal boat for many years and enjoyed a lot of holidays on it.
appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Edgar attends a club one day a fortnight and goes to church on Sundays. Edgar is not an active religous person but enjoys the church experience with a neighbour across the road. Edgar and her partner Ron (who passed away 5 years ago) used to own a canal boat for many years and enjoyed many trips on it. Edgar enjoys time in her garden, listening to books and/or the radio. Edgar is sight impaired which limits the things she can do.
appraisal2022.dietaryRequirementInfo: Edgar uses decaf tea and coffee. Easy to eat meals,are best for her. She can eat other meals eg sausages but would need assistance cuting up the food and loading her fork. She can use thr firk herself. Breakfast is usually cereal and juice  followed by a crumpet with marmalade. Edgar can eat this herself.
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine: Edgar gets up at about 7.30 and usually has a shower once up. Once dressed this is followed by breakfast. Usually a bowl of cereal, juice and a crumpet. Finishing with a cup of tea. Morning can be listening to the radio or a book but she often nods off during this. Lunch can be a sandwich/wrap some crisps and/or a piece of fruit. Evening meal can be anything from a frozen meal to a meal prepared by the carer. Edgar likes simple meas eg macaroni cheese, fish pie, sausage and mash etc. We ensure she has a glass of water nearby at all times.  Usually she has a cup of tea/coffee mid morning.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: Edgar uses a pad during the day and a "pull-up" at night. She self toilets but occaisionally cann't wipe herself properly which combined with her impaired vision may result in needing management of cleaning herself and toilet etc
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: Edgar can get herself out of bed to go to the toilet at night. This may be 3 times a night. She leaves the hall light on to facilitate this.

homeEnvironment2022.homeAccess: Coded key box in porch area if Edgar doesn't answer the door.

Buses run past the house regularily.

on daily medication
daily meds

appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow:
Diana has always been a very sociable person, but doesn’t want someone with her all the time.

She  will enjoy it if you eat together with her sometimes.

Generally mum won’t now initiate joint activities, but if you suggest it, sometimes she will enjoy a game of cards or dominoes.  Sometimes she likes to colour together with you - she has a number of  colouring books and pencils.

She will also enjoy sitting watching TV together…..she doesn’t like sports!  But enjoys gardening and wildlife programmes and also quiz problems.

Mum is very strong minded if she doesn’t like/want something and there is no point in trying to change her mind.

When she’s anxious she usually responds well to reassurance .  But this will need to be given repeatedly, as she forgets so quickly.  But remembers her worries



Sometimes she likes playing a game of cards if it is suggested
appraisal2022.interestsInfo:
Mum used to socialise  a lot more but gradually this has stopped as  her friends have all passed on. She has not wanted to go to any day centres or clubs although she did attend a bridge  club at U3A and  WP library   until her mobility and  cognition became more difficult
She has always  enjoyed  listening to  music &  would always have Radio 3  on  as classical music has  been  a great love  throughout her life - but  over the last year she has stopped putting the radio on.

Similarly she has always loved  to read the newspapers particularly the Guardian   and this  currently is her main activity , although she tends to read the same things over and over . She likes to read aloud  to people and still  does this easily 

She has also always been a keen gardener and  still gets alot of pleasure from looking at her garden . When the weather is OK  she likes to have  walk around  to see what is growing and what needs tending to .

But she can no longer manage the steps up to the main garden
appraisal2022.dietaryRequirementInfo: Mum gets great pleasure from her food these days and eats a lot!
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine:
Mum goes to bed anytime between 6.30 and 8.  we try to encourage her not to go to bed too early cos of waking in the night.  But often the pain in her groin makes her want to go to bed.  She may stay up a bit later if she's watching tv with you.

Mum has breakfast soon after getting up - she will let you know when she want it.  She has orange juice, tea (with a sweetener) and toast with jam - at least 3 slices.  Sometimes she might also like a hot cross bun/

She has lunch at about 12 and this is her main meal of the day.

It’s good if she can have freshly cooked food on at least 4 days.

chicken (crispy wings cooked in the oven or pieces) veg and potatoes/rice
Salmon or other fish fillets (oven cooked), veg and potatoes
Pasta cheese with salad (she loves baby tomatoes)

There will also be ready meals or pizza in the freezer.

Omlettes - cheese or mushroom particularly popular.

Vegetables - peas, asparagus, spinach, mushrooms, broccoli, green beans

She likes baby boiled pots and sometimes a baked potato (a meal of baked potato with cheese and salad she enjoys)

Fruit - grapes, berries - strawberries, raspberries, blueberries.

For desert she will have fruit, or yoghurt or crumble, etc.
She loves ice cream. 

In the evening about 5.30/6 she has a lighter meal......maybe soup and a sandwich or boiled eggs or  omelettes- mushroom, cheese are favourites

She will eat snacks in addition to her meals.  Biscuits/cake, crackers and cheese.  whatever she fancies/is in the fridge/cupboard.

Drinks - tea (with a sweetener) first thing, coffee mid morning, tea in the afternoon.
 She enjoys a glass of squash particularly when it’s warm.
appraisal2022.washingSupportOther: Mum doesn’t always wash thoroughly and needs additional help
appraisal2022.continenceSupportOther:
Has a commode in her bedroom, but generally won’t use it.
She uses pads/padded pants pads.  She worries about wetting herself, but mostly is not incontinent.  
But she may not get to the toliet in time due to her very slow mobility.

She regularly needs assistance with adjusting  her clothing .

Even with medication she generally wakes several times a night to go to the toilet - between 4 and 9 times currently
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo:
Diana can be left on her own for short periods in the day time whilst carer pops to the shop - 15/20 mins .

Diana can be left on her own during the day, so long as you are in earshot to hear if she needs anything.  Sometimes she needs reassurance that she’s not alone.

At night she can be left to fall asleep, but sometimes needs help to get her legs on the bed.

She has a hospital bed which is lowered at night, as she has previously fallen getting out of bed.


Re night times Diana has said this

'Sometimes I wake up at night and am confused about the time & think it's morning &  time to get up. I can get quite upset & / or insistent about this .

So please speak kindly &  remind me that it is still dark outside because it is nighttime,   and help me to lie back down & relax back to sleep.  There is also a specialist clock next to my bed to remind me what time of day or night it is .

At times I will insist on getting up, dressed and having breakfast.  There is no point in trying to dissuade me when I do.

Also the osteo arthritis in my hip means I am in pretty much constant pain in my groin  & leg - usually on the left but some times on both sides.

This makes getting out of bed painful

I do have medication for this but nothing seems to get rid of the pain completely and some times it wakes me up' 

There is a notebook in the house to write down all the times  Diana wakes up. As this is being monitored by the GP
appraisal2022.behavioursNeedingInterventionMoreInfo: only when waking in the night and thinking it is morning - this tends to happen if she falls asleep whilst still dressed in the evening but since going to bed earlier less of an issue although  does still happen and then wants breakfast  - but will go back to sleep afterwards

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: She has frontotemporal dementia. She is articulate but often repeats herself on a loop. She resists care and insists she does not need it, but has now become good friends with carer who visits daily. She cannot cook or use kitchen because she has caused several kitchen fires and devices have to be disabled: she relies on deliveries of hot meals. She is fit and active and mobile but is not safe out walking and police have told us that she should not go out alone. She has 2-3 hours of care per day but when unattended is at risk because of this. Her memory is very poor and she lacks insight and is in denial about her condition.

appraisal2022.interestsInfo: She was a cat breeder in the past but has not had cats for twenty years. She loves going for walks in country and gardening. She is physically fit and used to go to gym but after an operation has not done it for last three years. Her interests in reading and local social events were important but have faded away with dementia.
appraisal2022.behavioursNeedingInterventionMoreInfo: Her wandering has been flagged as dangerous to herself and others by police. She also often brings things home that do not belong to her. Neighbours and police have been involved. She is in denial about memory loss and can get angry and frustrated when people tell her this. She resisted having a carer at first but has now become good friend with her in past four months. She is prone to hoarding and other obsessive behaviours.

General day to day support, prompts, reminders, guidance, maggie is unsafe to use appliances in the kitchen, so would need someone to cook and prepare her meals. Someone who can provide companionship and mental stimulation. Keep her safe.  Nights - sleeps well, and sleeps through.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: Although I have cerebral palsy, my current state is temporary. Usually I can walk but as I have broken my bone, this is why I need all the extra support.

prescribedMedications.name: Ramipril
prescribedMedications.howIsObtained: I will have it with me

prescribedMedications.name: cerelle
prescribedMedications.howIsObtained: I'll have it with me

appraisal2022.recipientLife: I work from home and run a business called Celebrating Disability. It is a disability inclusion businesse and we enable businesses to develop inclusive cultures for disabled employees and customers. I live on my own (out of choice) and have an active social life. I try to be as independent as possible and have developed many strategies to manage on my own. I can self direct my support. In my spare time, I love reading, watching true crime and drama (as well as anything else really!), Going out for meals, drinking (not heavily) seeing family on occasion, seeing friends, going to gigs. My favourite person is Robbie Williams! If you don't like Robbie Williams, perhaps we won't fit LOL
appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow: People assume because I'm disabled I can't think for myself or I am in my situation due to lack of opportunities. People need to know that I've chosen to be single and have no children. I really enjoy my life. I also really need people to know that I am very independent. I do not want to be talked down to or for assumptions to be made about me. I would call myself a feminist and definitely a disability activist. For the care support needs, I need somebody to support me to do the things I can't do myself, I'm not needing a new friend. But that is not saying that I don't want to be friendly and get on with the person that is supporting me. I just mean that I do not need a companion.
appraisal2022.interestsInfo:
My perfect person to work with is somebody who is easy-going, fun loving but also can entertain themselves. 

Recently, I broke my ankle. I went from being a person that can completely weight bare and walk around to a full-time wheelchair user. Therefore, my needs have changed dramatically. They will change back hopefully by the end of March but in the meantime, this is why I need to live in support.

I'm still running my business, and I still want to go out and do things with my friends but at the moment, I just might need a bit more support to do this. I would say the majority of the job will be on call but you will need to be available to help me to the loo when I need to. Occasionally, I will need you to come out with me either for a work event or a social event.

I would say as well that I am a pretty flexible person so if there is anything that has come up for the person that they would like to do during the day, if I can, I will try to accommodate it.

This role will also include general housework (including laundry), cooking and cleaning.
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine: Wash in the morning, coffee while I'm getting dressed, starting to work if on a workday, relaxing if not or going out and socialising. I don't really have a routine
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: At the moment, I'm using a commode
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: Don't need attendance. I need help to do the things that I physically can't do myself only

appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow: She likes to keep warm, a nice cup of tea and a biscuit. She can see/hear a little bit on the telly. She enjoys her garden and looking at old photos. She can walk round the garden with assistance, or likes a trip out in the car. She has a portable wheelchair for outings which fits in a normal car boot.
appraisal2022.interestsInfo: She used to teach young children in schools and at Poole Hospital. She learnt some French in retirement and loved her holidays with Donald (her husband passed away recently.) She loves to visit the seaside.
appraisal2022.dietaryRequirementInfo:
No cheese or onions. 
Easy to chew food please.
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine:
She will probably get up around 9am and go to bed around 9-10pm. She likes to go out if she's feeling up to it. 
Bran flakes for breakfast are good for her bowel problems. A light lunch, cup of tea and biscuit/cake at team time, light supper. Gaviscon tablet after evening meal.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: She may get constipation, which interferes with her catheter, or diarrhoea.
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: Stacey have provided care for Sylvia now 4 times and they have a set routine where Stacey usually takes a break at around 1-2pm . Can be left alone but not more than 20 minutes at a time.

homeEnvironment2022.homeNeighbourhood: A large residential esatate. The house is right next to a primary school. The house numbers dont go in order so can be difficult to find. They are the third house on thr left after thr school. Quiet village with a local shop in walking distance.

appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Rod used to paint as a hobby but is no longer able. He was also very good at DIY but has lost that ability. He was a competent sailor with qualifications to skipper a yacht up to 50 feet. He  used to have a pilots licence for a twin engine with instrument rating. He was an excellent skier and enjoyed skydiving.
appraisal2022.continenceSupportOther: Needs help to clean up after a BM. He sometimes urinates on the floor and has been bowel incontinent on the floor.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: His incontinence pants are usually clean and dry. He sometimes struggles with the button and zipper on his jeans and doesn’t get them off in time.
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: If he’s left unattended he will start wandering around the house looking for me. He leaves taps running and cannot always find the bathroom if needed. He becomes anxious. He doesn’t intentionally try to use the stove but I worry about it. He could fall and not be able to get up.
appraisal2022.behavioursNeedingInterventionMoreInfo: Rod has been aggressive both verbally and physically in the last 3 years. He still can be if asked to do something he doesn’t want to do. His mobility now restricts his aggression but he is quite strong if he gets a hold. I can usually take myself somewhere safe when this happens. His aggression is less frequent now - about one episode a month. His aggression usually relates to difficulty with using the toilet.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo:
GP prescribes medication: two inhalers.
A recent examination by a respiratory specialist suggests that I don't have COPD but a lower level of asthma, which tends to be noticeable when I'm anxious or stressed  (Dr Thomas at Three Shires Hospital, January 2025)
Physio is self funded

Carpal tunnel to the left hand has been completed, though a continuation of massage and flexing is needed to regain full use the of hand, The right hand has been similarly treated .   
      The back operation was due on 20th January 2025 at Three Shires Hospital, Northampton  (Circle Group) under the direction of Mr Rasul, consultant neurologist and back surgeon, NHS patient)  There was a major BooBoo by the hospital administration:  one party agreed that the operation should go ahead, another marked it for declining. So o 20th January, I stood, Nil by mouth etc at 07.30 hrs with my overnight bag and a sack of my usual medications, to be told that I wasn't on the List for that day. Mrs Rasul, similarly, stood with knife in one hand and MRI scan in the other with no Thomas in front of him.  All parties were very apologetic.  The operation is now to be conducted at UHCW (University Hospital Coventry and Warwick) - Coventry,  still by Mr Rasul.  There he has better equipment to deal with the twist in my spine and the back up of an ICU.  A silver lining!   Mr Rasul said it would be "soon".  I do, however, now have a date: 23rd February 2026. We now need to reinstate the previous arrangements, preferably with Wanda Berger. She has offered to continue to be my number one choice.

The constriction of the arteries taking blood to the lower limbs is causing the BP in the lower legs (feet) to be slightly lower.  I have been prescribed blood thinner to alleviate this problem.  The leg is under pressure from the BP difference causing the leg (esp. left leg) to be swollen and itchy.  Previously. I had been checked for DVT in the left leg, and this was not substantiated: I consider that this may have been the early warning of PAD.  I have been told that should my feet become very cold, I should go to A&E immediately. (Danger of gangrene) 
This condition was found when undergoing pre=operative assessment.

appraisal2022.medicalDeviceInfo: I use a walking stick and for longer walking (shopping, etc) I now use a rollator onto which I can put some of my weight, and off my back and legs

prescribedMedications.name: Spironolactone
prescribedMedications.howIsObtained: Thomas requests repeat prescriptions on line (4 week periods) for collection from the pharmacy

appraisal2022.interestsInfo:
I belong to the u3a and enjoy being an active member of the cycling group.  This has been curtailed because of my current multiple health issues.  Gardening, playing the piano (keyboard), DIY and other crafts/ maintenance jobs, now stopped because of the health issues. However, listening to my cd / disc music collection is still accessible, and enjoyed when I've got an infrequent spare minute or two! Planning the refurbishment of the spare room has been a great booster since Rita has had to go into care for remission, whilst I am unable to provide sufficient care for her myself.  I am being encouraged to sort, plan, reassess my extensive wardrobe by our weekly "home help". This is a challenge! And I like to help and be involved with other people!
Since this was written, I need to add that is quite unlikely that Rita should retrun home for care as her dementia is advancing, and her personal needs are quite extesnive, with a stoma bag permanetly needed. She has mishaps when going for a wee, missing the pan sometimes, and then getting soiled.  Otherwise she is managing very well, lnows her name etc, but does have short term memory blackout, and other confusions.  It is suggested that a move back home at this stage may upset her stability.
appraisal2022.dietaryRequirementInfo: I enjoy cooking and baking, and I enoy eating the results!  I do enjoy my food, and my portion sizes are usually too large. However, I do have  very varied diet, with possibly a little too much of certain components (eg salt, sugar) A recent MRI scan had indicated a degree of colonic diverticulation, at a level expected for my age.
appraisal2022.washingSupportOther:
currently, no assistance needed but when the hand is bandaged up it may be helpful to have some degree of supervision;
when the back surgery is completed, a more comprehensive regime will be needed for showering.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: No problems, just the nocturnal amble/shuffle to spend a penny!  And this may be more difficult after the back surgery. at the last back surhery, which was six years ago, the impact o the nightly suffle was minimal - it just takes longer to get to the toilet!
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: n/a

adDescription:
Thomas is having back surgery on his spinal cord and having the 3,4,5 fused together so will need some support when he comes out of hospital.

He has a carer coming in from 12th March to the 19th but will need someone potentially from the 1st of March until the 12th of March until the other carer comes in.

homeEnvironment2022.homeNeighbourhood: This is a long established area of residential housing on the south-eastern edge of town. (Northampton) There is a green space along the river valley, and part of this is a caravan camping park with many amenities,, including indoor swimming pool and amusements. (Billing Aquadrome) Within 15 minutes walk is vary comprehensive shopping centre with a dominating Tesco Extra Hypermarket (Weston Favell Centre)  There is a Number 16 bus route that takes you into the town centre, and a further bus would take you to the mainline rail station of Northampton, with easy access to Milton Keynes, onwards to London and in the other direction, to Birmingham. Our little community is just five bungalows, built sixteen years ago, as an "infill", and accessed behind existent housing. The area is well served with cycleways, various places of worship, as well as cinemas, and other entertainment facilities.
homeEnvironment2022.otherDomesticSupport: We would expect the appointed carer to "join in" with the daily running of the home, especially with laundry associated with the client's needs.  And offer their own spin on cooking some meals, ideas for maintaining a clean, comfortable and happy home.  We will expect the carer to keep their own private bedsitting room clean and tidy, too, as it will double as a guest bedroom for family when the carer may be absent.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: This does not really affect Malcolm.  The only thing holding Malcolm back is his frailty which at age 97, 98 in April, can be forgiven.

appraisal2022.medicalDeviceInfo: He has used a hoist to assist him getting out of bed but he has moved on from this now and is managing without this.
appraisal2022.fallsReasonOther: Trying to get to the toilet in time.
appraisal2022.skinIssuesInfo: He currently has a bed sore which has improved immensely under the watchful care of the his friend who is a retired GP and the district nurse. It is no longer a concern as such and the bed he now has adjusts his position to help prevent this going forward.
appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Malcolm was a successful Entrepreneur  in the clothes and mail order catalogue sector.  Alongside that he was instrumental in setting up a property company which still operates today in Hebden Bridge.  He has an unprecedented love for life, laughter and fun.    He loves nothing more than to go to out for lunch with his friends and family and talk of times past, and share jokes with a good mix of banter.  He is mentally very agile for his age, a little forgetful occasionally but largely very with it.  He has travelled around the world twice, and enjoys his holidays in the family apartment in Spain until his fall there last October where he unfortunately fell and broke his femur.  He was successfully operated on and is making a slow and remarkable recovery .  He has private physiotherapy three times a week and with help managing to get out of bed and take a few steps on a zimmer frame.  He wears disposable pants and needs help with changing these as he is not yet using a comode.  He is quietly determined to get back walking with his stick as soon as possible and get back to his routine of pub lunches and socialising.  He is physically very fragile though and unsteady on his feet (even before his fall in October).  We feel he will need a live in carer until his time with us is no more.  He is fun to be around and has a wicked sense or humour which can be  naughty and cheeky at times!
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: As he improves mobility he will work towards using a commode and eventually a toilet again.
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: Sometimes Malcolm likes his own space as well as someone to have a sing song with or to watch TV with but he will advise what his wishes are. He would respect a 2 hour break but it would be better to have those working around Malcolm's needs.

adDescription:
***LIVE IN CARE NEEDED - AMAZING MAN***

Meet Malcolm – 97 Years Young & Full of Life!

A true “cheeky chappy” with a big personality and great sense of humour

Outgoing, chatty, and loves engaging company

Recently recovering from a femur fracture after a fall

Currently receiving 24-hour care, but finds multiple caregivers confusing

Looking for a long-term, live-in carer for consistent, one-to-one support

Needs someone upbeat, warm, and able to match his fun, energetic spirit

Keen to stay motivated with rehabilitation and remain happily at home

Supported by a close family and a best friend who’s a retired doctor

Malcolm is ready to welcome a carer who’ll share laughs, offer steady support, and become a trusted companion in his home.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: Anne has been diagnosed with Alzheimers which is in the early stages. This manifests itself in poor short term memory (eg she may often repeat a question). She has some confusion about time and space – sometimes not recognising where she is (eg do I live here?), not remembering facts about the present (eg may ask about family and friends long deceased); sometimes going to the door because she thinks the doorbell has rung. She is being supported by the Memory Team in Cardiff and has support from a link worker and occupational therapist as needed. The way this manifests is variable. Sometimes she is as sharp as a button and quick witted, other times she can get confused. This often coincides with waking up - trying to reorientate herself - and tiredness

Anne has had fractures in vertebrae after falling, likely to be a result of osteoporosis. She has annual infusions for bone strengthening. She is likely to need an outpatient procedure within the next few months to help support the vertebrae. Her mobility is a little restricted because of this.
Anne has hearing aids which are very effective. It can be difficult to communicate when she is not wearing them.

Anne has a pacemaker and medication for this condition. It is well managed. She has a monitor in her bedroom which sends data from the pacemaker to a specialist team and has an annual review with the team
Anne's blood pressure is managed effectively with medication

appraisal2022.fallsReasonOther: some confusion and rushing to do things
appraisal2022.interestsInfo:
Anne is 92 and lives in a two bedroomed flat in Cardiff. Anne's first name is Frances but she goes by Anne.
She lives alone and would value companionship. She’s very sociable and people enjoy interacting with her.
She can engage fully in social interactions. Sometimes she needs encouragement to participate in activities. 
Anne has been diagnosed with Alzheimers which is in the early stages. This manifests itself in poor short term memory (eg she may often repeat a question) Confusion about time and space – sometimes not recognising where she is (eg do I live here?), not remembering facts about the present (eg may ask about family and friends long deceased); sometimes going to the door because she thinks the doorbell has rung. 
Has recently had a fall (January 4th 2026) and fractured a vertebrae so her mobility is temporarily reduced and as a result, she has been receiving more help with daily tasks than usual. She needs an aid to walk as she is unsteady on her feet. She gets quite tired easily and so needs regular rest and needs to be reminded to rest as she would like to keep doing things. 
Has a supportive family. (3 daughters, 5 grandchildren)
Sometimes gets up at night but can usually manage this herself.
Prior to the fall she was  living independently. Can usually take care of her own daily needs. Uses TV, ipad and phone proficiently.
Wears hearing aids and manages them independently
 
Generally Anne eats food prepared from scratch. She can  prepare her own breakfast
Lunch can be a light meal e.g Ham sandwich/Boiled eggs and toast/soup and toast/Tinned fish on toast/beans on toast/omelette/
Supper can be fish (white fish or salmon roasted, potatoes and vegetables/ready meals/)
She would need help to make something like cauliflower cheese 
Anne is a practising Roman Catholic. She goes to church on a Sunday morning and often on a Friday. Her religion is a central part of her life .
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: Anne is generally continent. She wears pads at night and is able to look after her toileting needs. She uses a commode at night. She sometimes needs help with mobility
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: Anne would like to remain as independent as possible. For the last 6 weeks since her spinal injury she has had support at home every day and most nights. She has started to spend more time alone in the past week. She is now mobilising well around her flat with a walking aid. When she is very tired she needs more help.

appraisal2022.fallsReasonOther: Had partial hip replacement in November and uses Zimmer frame
appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Rita enjoys very much taking part in these activities but needs encouragement to do them due to her dementia. She also enjoys jigsaws.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: Awaiting appointment with a incontinence team following referral from GP
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: Rita is usually ok to leave when sleeping in her bedroom and occasionally gets up to use toilet

adDescription:
We are seeking a compassionate and experienced female live-in carer to support an elderly lady in her own home.

About Rita:

93-year-old lady

Living with dementia

Physically in reasonable condition

Requires supervision, reassurance, and day-to-day support

Currently receiving a mix of hourly care and waking night support (now unsustainable)

Current Situation:

Rita’s son-in-law, Ian, and daughter, Katrina, are arranging care

Katrina has been primary caregiver

Family circumstances have recently changed, creating urgency

Family seeking a more sustainable, long-term live-in solution

Care Requirements:

Full-time live-in support

Assistance with personal care

Support with daily routines and meal preparation

Companionship and reassurance

Dementia-aware approach

Carer will require appropriate daily breaks

Start Date:

Ideally within the next couple of weeks

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: She has a anti depressant as GP thought it could help uplift her mood as she sometimes feels abit hopeless

appraisal2022.discriminationDetails: Grandma used to have night carers who were different races and she would say things to them which were hurtful and tends to be less compliant.
appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Socialisations and getting her out and about for short walks or with the wheelchair or even just in the garden weather permitting
appraisal2022.continenceSupportOther: Grandma needs help going to commode. She can then use this herself. She al has wears a pad just in case - reliant in pad through night
appraisal2022.behavioursNeedingInterventionMoreInfo: She can be challenging when there is a need for personal care. Eg says no when there is a clear need for her to go to the toilet or change her pad. Can sometimes be resistant with washing and feels she can do everything herself so if a carer tries to help  she can become challenging

adDescription:
PERMANENT PLACEMENT
START DATE: 26th May
LOCATION: Hill Brow, GU33 8AJ
NEAREST STATION: Wigan South Eastern
Irene needs a live-in carer as her dementia is advancing. She needed support with most aspects of life, such as mobility and safely moving around the house. She had a fall and ended up in the hospital. She also needs help with personal care, food & drink and domestic support and administering her medication
She enjoys socialising and getting out and about for a short walk, or with the wheelchair, or even just in the garden, weather permitting. The carer would have their own bedroom and private bathroom. Please note that due to her condition, Irene can sometimes say hurtful and discriminatory things to carers from certain backgrounds. 
NO PETS
WIFI
BREAK GUARANTEED

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: Largely just forgetful.

appraisal2022.interestsInfo:
Sadie worked two jobs all her life and brought up three kids. Father passed ten years ago. Worked in the community and spent a lot of time working with charities. Involved with Saint William's Church. Comes from a mining family in the North East. 

Enjoys getting out for a coffee or walks in the park.

adDescription:
We are looking for someone to do Thu-Sun on an ongoing basis with a view to eventually going full time.

Care Needs: Early stages Dementia. Just helping Sadie put together her day effectively and provide companionship. She would also love to start going to church again as well
Driver's License/Car: Not required, but would be a good addition.
Start Date: Mid January - Flexible
Location: Leeds. Easily accessible.
Benefits: free travel and access to e-learning
Night Time Needs: Low. Less than once per night
Breaks: CR okay to be left alone

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: Phyllis is currently in a care home (discharge to assess) after recovering from a respiratory infection and UTI, for which she was hospitalised.

appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Phyllis likes to play scrabble and cards; read her book and watch TV. She used to enjoy good conversation but following 2 infections her capacity has deteriorated and her thought processes change frequently during conversation. She enjoys talking about flowers/things in the garden, her life growing up and she likes watching quiz programmes on the TV like The Chase and Countdown.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: Phyllis wears incontinence pants during the night as she was inconsistent with getting out of bed and using the commode and wetting the bed. She knows to mobilise during the day however when she needs the toilet.
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: It is a little unknown at the moment as to how she will be on returning home from the care home where she currently requires 1:1 support

adDescription:
ONGOING CARE PLACEMENT IN Calderdale (HX3)
NEAREST TRAIN STATION: Ivybridge / Calderdale

We are looking for a live-in carer to support Phyllis, 94, who is currently in a rehabilitation Care Home and due to come home soon. Phyllis is increasingly frail and needs a gentle and patient touch to help her with mobility, personal care and support with activities of daily living. 

Phyllis will be living downstairs upon her arrival back at home and the carer will therefore have the upstairs of the property to themselves. Her daughter Stephanie lives locally and works from home at Phyllis's property three days a week so there is plenty of support and breaks available for the carer. The home is in a residential area of Calderdale within walking distance of shops, amenities and the coast.

NO PETS
WIFI
BREAK GUARANTEED
LOW NIGHT SUPPORT NEEDED

prescribedMedications.name: Paracetamol + Ibuprofen
prescribedMedications.howIsObtained: Paracetamol at home - if runs out daughter will obtain

prescribedMedications.name: Diclofenac

appraisal2022.mistreatmentDetails: When experiencing periods of confusion and frustration, mainly on an evening and during the night, Leonard can sometimes shout and use swear words at those caring for him.
appraisal2022.recipientLife: Dad was born in the west of ireland. He had 2 brothers and 3 sisters. They lived on a farm and didn’t have much. He moved to England do work when he was 20 years old. One of his brothers was here before him so he came to meet him. He worked all his life in construction doing manual work in a time before machinery. He met his wife Rita in leeds and they had one daughter. Rita passed away in 2015. Most people call dad Sean (it’s Irish for Leonard). He is close to his friends and family who often visit him. He has a daughter. nieces and nephew who regularly visit. He likes sport- mainly football and rugby and enjoys watching this on tv. Liverpool and Leeds United are his favourite teams but he will watch any. He is a catholic and likes to say his prayers too and watch mass on tv on a Sunday.
appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow: His is an intelligent man. He can get frustrated that he can no longer do the things he could do before. He is also quite deaf so you may need to speak loud and clear for him to understand.
appraisal2022.dietaryRequirementInfo: He likes traditional food - meat veg potatoes kind of stuff. He likes a fry up (bacon/egg/sausages etc some mornings). He has porridge every morning
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine: Morning he has porridge with linseeds. Then he has a drink of honey, ground ginger and lemon (with hot water). Then mid morning he may like a bacon sandwich. He likes to watch the news on tv. At luck he usually has a sandwich, with cups of tea. He drinks water regularly and likes a glass next to him. He usually has his dinner around 4.30pm. He usually goes to bed around 10pm/11pm however since being in hospital this has been earlier as he has not been sleeping great at night so is more tired during the day.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: Can use the toilet but needs help getting there. Uses commode sometimes
appraisal2022.behavioursNeedingInterventionMoreInfo: Sundowning, sometimes can be inpatient when needing the toilet, confusion on day/time. Can sometimes swear with frustration at not being able to do things

adDescription:
PERMANENT PLACEMENT 
START DATE: 20th January
LOCATION: Flintshire, LL11

Currently seeking care support for an elderly gentleman called Leonard, 85. He is coming home after being in respite care and needs support with personal care, meal preparation, household help, domestic chores and companionship. He enjoy watching the football, listening to the radio and lots of cups of tea!

NO PETS
WIFI
BREAK GUARANTEED
NIGHT SUPPORT NEEDED

homeEnvironment2022.homeNeighbourhood: Safe area. Lovely neighbours who all look out for each other.
homeEnvironment2022.homeRules: No smoking indoors. No visitors to the property.

medicalConditionsInfo.description:
He had 2 pretty large strokes in relatively quick succession back in September 2021.

Unfortunately this has left him currently being unable to have any mobility down his one side. He is undergoing physical therapy at the nursing home currently but its in its early stages.

The stoke has also severely impacted his ability to communicate (speech, reading and writing). Again his rehabilitation therapy is ongoing in the nursing home currently but its in its early stages.

assessment.lifeOutsideHome:
He is very sociable and everyone in his village knows him. He would typically go out to see his friends across at the pub a couple of times a week.

He is very into sports (especially football). He has played football all his life (well into his late 50s) and in the last few years was even part of a walking football team prior to his stroke. He also loves to watch sports on television also (again especially football). 

Like a lot of people, he has always liked going on holidays (Spain, Greece etc) and in recent years (prior to his stoke) he has rented an apartment on the Costa del Sol in Spain for a few months at a time (and typically has done this at least twice a year for probably the last 10+ years).

medications.name: Amlodipine
medications.directions: Amlodipine 5mg   Take one in the morning.

medications.name: Clopidogrel
medications.directions: Clopidogrel 75mg    Take one in the morning.

medications.name: Lansoprazole
medications.directions: Lansoprazole 15mg   Take one in the morning.

medications.name: Ramipril
medications.directions: Ramipril 1.25 mg   Take one in the morning.

assessment.medicationRefill: Currently he is in a nursing home undergoing rehabilitation so the nursing home take care of the refills whilst he is in there.

dailyRoutine.nightTimeCare: He sleeps well at night. He is able to move and change position for comfort. He likes a drink left within easy reach. He would not be able to use the toilet during the night and would need to use pads.
dailyRoutine.foodDietDescription:
He eats a normal regular diet and has a good appetite.

He needs his food cut into manageable pieces as he can only use his left hand. All food needs to be prepared for him.
dailyRoutine.personalCare: He needs full assistance from one person to wash and dress. He could take a shower in a shower chair again with the assistance of one .He can clean his own teeth and comb his hair once all equipment is provided within easy reach. He would not be able to manage nail or foot care.
dailyRoutine.continenceDescription:
He can ask for and use the toilet without issue. However, he can be incontinent of urine and bowels on odd occasions if not taken to the toilet with some small degree of urgency.

He has a supply of pads to use which will be supplied for him at home.
dailyRoutine.mobilityDescription:
For transfers he uses a patient turner. He has very good strength in his left side and stands easily with one to assist with all transfers.

He uses a wheelchair for mobility within the home. In addition, his home is in the process of being fitted with a stair lift so he can access both downstairs and upstairs.

adDescription: Live in care for a gentleman who had a stroke in 2021. Prior to the stroke he was very active - playing football and going on holiday. Now he needs some full time assistance to help him adjust to living at home. He is a really positive gentleman with a good sense of humour and would appreciate a carer who can joke with him and brings some life to his home.

careEnvironment.petsText: There are no pets in the house. The only pet who will visit the house is his daughter's dog who she may occasionally bring over when she visits him for an hour or so.
careEnvironment.householdDescription:
He lives on his own in a 3 story townhouse in a quiet cul-de-sac in a large village (Kinver) which is located on the edge of the West Midlands conurbation. Obviously with the house being over 3 storeys is an issue for his lack of mobility but we are in the process of having stairlifts installed prior to him returning home.

The house has a garage, toilet, utility room and garden room on ground floor. The house has a kitchen and living room on first floor. The house has a master bedroom (with en-suite), two bedrooms and a separate bathroom on the second floor. The house also has a small garden at the rear, as well as 2 car driveway in front of the house.

Kinver is a large village but with many amenities (shops, supermarket, post office, pubs, restaurants, schools etc) there, all typically within no more than 10-15 mins walking distance of the house. The village is also just a few miles from the nearest big towns of Stoubridge, Dudley and Kidderminster and is well connected by road (as well as an hourly bus service).
careEnvironment.domesticSupportDescription:
Currently he is undergoing early stages of his rehabilitation so quite a lot of support will be required in the short term. This will most likely include pretty much all domestic aspects (i.e. washing, cleaning, tidying, cooking) as well as having to either assist him or go on his behalf to supermarket, post office etc

However we are hopeful that as his rehabilitation continues he will be able to become more independent in certain domestic activities in the future, but at this moment in time he will need full domestic support due to his lack of mobility.
careEnvironment.groceries: Due to his mobility issues, the carer will have to go to the supermarket to buy food and any household supplies that are required. There is a small convenience store in the village that sells the basics. For large supermarkets, there are several to choose from within a few miles away (either Stourbridge or Kidderminster).
careEnvironment.carerBreakDescription:
He can be left for several hours at a time and he is actually very content with this. So the carer will have ample opportunities to take rest throughout the day and night.

However, given obviously his mobility issues, the timings of the break would probably need to be outside of typical meal times (e.g. breakfast time, lunchtime or dinnertime). Other than that he probably will be very happy to be left in the living room or garden room etc for large parts of the day so it is extremely unlikely the carer should be needed constantly throughout the day.

medicalConditionsInfo.description: Following some small strokes some time ago Ken has short term memory issues. He therefore has trouble remembering what he has been told and tends to repeat himself
As you would expect at 96 Ken’s hearing is deteriorating. Ken has hearing aids and when used these greatly increase his hearing capacity.

Ken  broke his hip in a fall in 2021 and he has been in hospital. His mobility prior the hip break was not good and he needed a Zimmer frame to walk. His mobility now is very limited and the use of a Sara Steady is required to move him around his bunglow

assessment.lifeOutsideHome: Ken does not have hobbies as such, but he likes to read the paper, watch TV, have a glass of wine and to go out for a drive and a coffee with the family.

medications.name: zero base emollient
medications.directions: Ken suffers with facial dry skin and requires zerobase emollient to be applied three times per week

dailyRoutine.nightTimeCare: Ken’s sleep pattern is generally good, but he sometimes has bad nights  and he occasionally gets anxious at night with bad dreams. He will settle with reassurance.
dailyRoutine.challengingBehaviour:
Ken has a sense of humour and being from an older generation he thinks it is a leg-pull to ask female Carers for a kiss or a cuddle. He is never sexually explicit and would not swear and he would not inappropriately touch anyone. The best way to deal with this is to ignore him, or just fend off the comments. Due to his short term memory loss he may say these type of things quite often. There is no intent, or malice.
All in all Ken is very compliant when directed, it’s only when he is very tired that he may become resistant.
dailyRoutine.foodDietDescription:
Tea and toast after waking.

Coffee at 11/11.30 approx

Glass of non-alcoholic wine at 13.00, lunch at 13.30 approx.

Sandwich and cake at 6/7pm approx.

Chris will provide the weekly food.

Ken needs to be given water/cordial throughout the day to ensure he is hydrated.
dailyRoutine.personalCare:
Ken will require help with washing, being given drinks, meals, medication, dressing and toileting. There are some incontinence issues, however, this has been managed very well by the use of conveen devices.
Ken’s family will undertake food shopping, preparing meals etc and will take the Carer food shopping as required.

Ken should be showered and shaved at least twice per week. Prompting to clean teeth daily. Finger nails to be cut as required. Toe nails are managed by a visiting chiropodist. Strip washes at the carers’s discretion.
dailyRoutine.continenceDescription: Ken had continence issues and used to wears pads. The conveen devices have replaced these.. His mobility is sometimes an issue in him reaching the toilet and prompting may help.
dailyRoutine.attendanceRequirementDetails: Chris (son) will make themselves available to support carers. There is also an arrangement in place for external Carers to attend to ensure breaks are provided for the live in carer.
dailyRoutine.fallDetails: The broken hip was the result of a fall and Ken is in hospital now. The falls I believe would be less if he were assisted. Since Ken has been in hospital I have not been able to gauge his mobility, but I am told he can walk with a frame.
dailyRoutine.mobilityDescription: Ken can stand briefly, but require the use of the Sara Steady to get around the house.

adDescription:
Live in carer needed for Ken. Ken has a broken hip and so would appreciate the support of a carer in the household. Ken would need assistance with his personal care, mobility, general housework and food preparation. 

MUST HAVE EXPERIENCE IN THE FOLLOWING:  the use of Conveen external urinary catheter  & The Sara Stedy mobility device. Both are apart of Ken's daily life and routine.

Breaks guaranteed.

During the night Ken may call out but just requires the reassurance that a carer is in the home and he will quickly settle back to sleep again.

careEnvironment.householdDescription:
Ken lives alone in a three bedroomed bungalow in a very nice part of Barry. There are sea views and parks just minutes away from the house. The nearest station is Barry which is 1.4 miles away. There is a bus service that serves the area. The biggest supermarket (Asda) is 1.6 miles away, but all food shopping and anything required will be provided by Chris.

Visits will be from family and will take place 3/4 times a week.
careEnvironment.domesticSupportDescription: Prior to Ken going into hospital a cleaner would come in once a week, that arrangement can continue if required. Ken’s washing would be undertaken by the carer.
careEnvironment.carerBreakDescription: This will require further discussion between both parties, but Ken’s family will play a part in ensuring breaks can be taken.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: Grace takes sertraline for his anxiety.

Grace has a fractured pelvis that has not healed in the right condition so he requires support to transfer.  We have Mackworth, commode, wheelchair and zimmer frame. Physio advises weight bearing only.

appraisal2022.fallsReasonOther: Over confident and forgot zimmer frame lost balance

adDescription: Ongoing live-in care for a lovely gentleman with physical disability. He lives with his wife who plays a supporting role. Support with personal care, dressing, general support around the house. No night time concerns

appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Christian - would love to go to Church on a Sunday. 80s music, loves Star Trek.

adDescription:
ONGOING CARE PLACEMENT IN Little Billing, NORTHAMPTON (NN3)
START DATE: Saturday 24th January
NEAREST TRAIN STATION: Little Billing, NORTHAMPTON & Cartmel (1 mile away from home address)

We are looking for a live-in carer to support Donald, 51, with his daily living at home. Donald has Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and has limited mobility - he uses a wheelchair. He is a lovely, sociable man but is generally housebound due to his MS and needs additional support at home with his mobility, personal care, household help and companionship. He does have some family support for his care but live-in care is now required to enable him to continue living as independently as possible at home. 

NO PETS
WIFI
BREAK GUARANTEED
NO NIGHT SUPPORT NEEDED

dailyRoutine.attendanceRequirementDetails: It is safe to leave Phyllis alone for up to a maximum of 2 hours.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo:
Phyllis was referred to the memory clinic several years ago due to a bit of confusion and forgetfulness but no clinical diagnosis of dementia was made and although there were signs of vascular change they were happy to discharge her with an invitation to get back in touch should things decline. 
Following a gradual decline in memory and cognitive ability as well as confusion, Phyllis is now awaiting a re referral appointment at the memory clinic. 
Due to this change in Phyllis’s behaviour, she needs someone with her twenty four hours a day, apart from carer breaks when she needs to be left with hot water bottle, drink and the television on at a programme of her choice. 

As of December 2025, following further assessment, Phyllis now has a formal clinical diagnosis of vascular dementia. It has also been noted that she has paranoia, anxiety and depression. She has been prescribed with Mirtazapine to treat this. Phyllis is unsure about what these tablets are for. We have told her they are to help with her memory problems and anxiety sunce she denies having paranoia or depression.

It’s actually rheumatoid arthritis, not osteoarthritis. It makes Phyllis extremely tired and often anaemic but her doctor checks her iron level periodically. Some days Phyllis just needs to stay at home quietly due to feeling weak and tired. An associated condition to her rheumatoid arthritis is sjorgren’s syndrome. It’s an auto immune response and means Phyllis does not produce any saliva which makes eating a bit tricky. She needs to have gravy or a runny sauce with each meal to aid swallowing. She hasn’t ever choked.

Phyllis has age related heart failure which is managed by her GP.  It means she gets out of breath following exertion such as going upstairs. She needs to sit on her bed to recover after going upstairs.

Phyllis needs to drink plenty of liquid, not necessarily just water, caffeine free tea and coffee are acceptable. However, Phyllis needs constant reminders and persuasion to do so as she is extremely averse to drinking which is why she has kidney failure.

Sometimes Phyllis’s blood pressure is high or even extremely high and sometimes it is low. It can change within  each day. Because of this, her GP had decided to stop medication to lower the BP in case it made her lose consciousness when was low. It’s a balancing act but in view of her recent TIA, it has been decided to restart her on the prevoius medication.
Phyllis has had several TIAs, the most recent one being in October 2025. She is awaiting an re referral to the stroke clinic.
Phyllis takes daily medication to strengthen her bones.

appraisal2022.recipientLife:
Phyllis was born in 1933 in South Shields. During the war, Phyllis and her mother lived in London but returned to Shields afterwards. 
In 1950, Phyllis married Maurice Yarrow and they lived together near The Nook. Maurice was in the Merchant Navy and spent many months at a time at sea. Whenever possible, Phyllis joined him and together they sailed around the world. While Maurice was at sea without Phyllis, she worked in a Building Society in South Shields. They had three daughters together, Suzanne, Louise and Oliver and moved to a lovely house in Cleadon. By now, Maurice had become a Master Mariner, but sadly, Maurice died when he was just 48 yrs old. Phyllis was only 45 at the time.
Phyllis has never remarried and still lives in the same house in Cleadon. 
Phyllis has always had a Christian faith and for many years, worshipped at St Mark and St Cuthbert's at Cleadon Park where she served for several years as Church Warden. Phyllis had always been artistic and took up Flower Arranging. She joined a flower club and they won many awards for the amazing arrangements they put together. Phyllis also arranged the flowers at church. 
Phyllis still manages to make the most beautiful masterpices from a bunch of ordinary flowers from the supermarket or an odd flower and some foilage from her garden! These days Phyllis has a gardener to keep her garden looking wonderful.
Phyllis loves to reminisce about her life and has a wealth of memories to relate. She loves visiting garden centers where she always enjoys a coffee or lunch. Having lived the majority of her life by the coast, she loves being driven along the sea front and stopping at car parks, esecially if they have a coffee kiosk, so she can sit enjoying a coffee whilst watching the waves. If the weather is fine, she might manage a little walk in the fresh air.
appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow:
Phyllis is quite shy and does not put herself forward yet if offered the chance to chat, she will readily reminisce.
 Watching tv is good, especially Emmerdale, Father Brown, Grantchester, The Chase, Tennis, period dramas and gardening programmes.
 A walk round her garden will always please her.
Since Phyllis tires easily, she benefits from watching the tv for a few hours in the either the morning or afternoon or both, where she dozes then wakes refreshed for the rest of the day. She prefers to sit in the back room in the morning because it's warm and sunny, then moves to the front room in the afternoon and evening.
An outing to a garden centre or a drive along the sea front several times each week is a welcome and beneficial change for her. She also likes lunch at local cafes now and again.
appraisal2022.interestsInfo:
Used to do: flower arranging, go to church, gardening, cooking, shopping.
Now: Phyllis likes to be taken to garden centres for coffee / lunch, other cafes for lunch / coffee, being driven along her very local coast line and stopping in car parks and maybe having a short walk, being involved with meal choices, food shopping and simple food prep, watching tv.
Phyllis is awaiting assessment at the memory clinic since she is showing  signs of confusion and forgetfulness. She is also showing signs of cognitive decline.
appraisal2022.dietaryRequirementInfo:
Since Phyllis suffers from Sjogren's Syndrome, she doesn't produce any saliva which means that her food usually needs to be accompanied by gravy unless it's a sloppy meal. Eating ordinary boiled or mashed potato is unpleasant due to it's dryness so Phyllis prefers boiled then mashed sweet potato which is much easier to eat. 
She has a small appetite.
Although Phyllis is happy to try food from around the world, she generally prefers a “ meat and two veg” type of meal with mashed sweet potato instead of ordinary potato.
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine:
Phyllis wakes between 7.30 and 9.30am. She goes to the toilet then downstairs, all independantly. Straight away she needs to be prompted to take her medication from the black tablet box (already prepared on a weekly basis by her daughter). She takes her tablets with warm water. By this time she is sometimes feeling lightheaded so needs to sit on the settee while the carer makes her a cup ot tea with a tiny bit of milk and prepares some fruit for her to eat. After a while she needs to be given one Weetabix in a bowl, with a tiny sprinkling of sugar, and milk and eats it at the table. 
If Phyllis is feeling well, she will go upstairs to wash and dress or shower and dress. Although she still showers herself, the carer needs to be around to help just in case she has any difficulties. After her shower the carer also needs to be available just in case she needs help to find items of suitable and warm enough clothing and possibly support her with dressing eg fastening her bra.
Following this Phyllis needs a sit down in the back room downstairs to recover from dressing and have a glass of chilled coffee drink from the fridge.
Phyllis likes to help decide what to eat each day. It helps her feel involved and independent if she can make suggestions and help with shopping lists. She often brings the subject up herself either before or after breakfast.
Phyllis likes a little outing once she's dressed, most days, if she's feeling well. She is very reticent to say if she's feeling unwell and in the past, has opted to go out when she clearly isn't up to it. Sometimes she is too polite for her own good so the carer will need to use their own judgement. She has favourite garden centres with cafes, other cafes or a walk down to the village or round the block or maybe just a walk round her garden, front and back. She finds it difficult to choose so it’s best to give her a choice of two venues and she will probably still ask the carer to choose. A list of venues and addresses will be given to the carer.
After a light lunch it will probably be near to the carers break. At this point, Phyllis will be in need of a rest herself. She will choose which room to sit in. She needs help turning on the tv and deciding what to watch. She also likes to be left with a hot water bottle. If it's not given to her she will go and get it herself but she is obviously in danger of scalding herself so always leave her with one.
After that it will be preparing the evening meal. Sometimes she likes to help by peeling the sweet potato and setting the table but that's about the limit. Phyllis likes a dessert such fresh raspberries or strawberries with a tiny sprinkling of sugar and some cream or other prepared desserts from the fridge.
After the evening meal, it's more tv in the front room. Always Emmerdale at 7.30 then she needs help to choose for the rest of the evening til 9pm when it's time for bed.
 The carer needs to prepare a fresh hot water bottle and put it in her bed just below her pillow. She also needs a small glass of warm water left on her bedside table and her handbag needs to be carried upstairs where she will "put it in a safe place". Phyllis usually gets ready for bed by herself but the carer needs to be available in case she needs help to undress, put on her nightie and place items of clothing into the wash. She can brush her teeth and use the toilet herself. She may need help to get into bed.  It is best that the Carer hovers to make sure she is settled in bed each evening before leaving her.
appraisal2022.continenceSupportOther: May need occasional reminder to go to the toilet but has never had an accident.
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo:
Since Phyllis is unsteady on her feet she needs watching from a distance in case she falls although she has only done so on two occasions. 
Before the carer goes on their break, they need to make sure Phyllis has the tv on the correct channel for what she wants to watch and also has a fresh hot water bottle otherwise she will get it herself which is not safe. 
There is a camera installed in the back room. Phyllis is not aware of this. It's just so we can check on Phyllis occasionally, for example sometimes when the carer is on their break. 
Very occasionally during the night, Phyllis gets confused about time and gets up and comes downstairs at 5am but then doesn’t know what to do. Before we had the camera she would sit in the cold and dark til the carer came down in the morning. Now that we've got the camera, we set the motion alarm for during the night and if Phyllis comes downstairs out of hours, we are alerted and can phone the carer to deal with the situation since it's unlikely that Phyllis would make enough noise to wake the carer. During the rest of the day, we don’t view the camera though it must always be left open. The camera is there for Phyllis's safety, not for spying on the carer.

appraisal2022.recipientLife:
Helen is originally from Sheffield. She used to work in Marks and Spencer’s, Boots and the GPO. She’s travelled to a lot of places around the world. She has been married to Alice for 68 years. She has 3 children, a son and twin daughters. She has a sweet tooth, loves chocolates and cakes!! She used to love sitting in the garden and listening to the birds, but it is now very difficult to get her outside as she gets scared in a wheelchair. She also used to love reading and crosswords before she lost her sight. She used to love sewing and knitting when she was able to. 

UPDATE: Helen's husband Alice died at home on 9th January 2026. She is obviously very upset and unsettled and needs lots of cuddles and emotional support.
appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow:
Things Helen likes:
Holding her hand
Giving her hugs 
Sitting with her and chatting
Stroking her hands/hair in bed
Reassuring her and being gentle
Listening to music

Things Helen does not like:
Because Helen is severely visually impaired, she doesn't like any sudden loud noises. She will no longer go in a car as she is too scared, so is effectively house-bound
appraisal2022.interestsInfo:
Sleeping 
Listening to music
Eating sweet things and a hot drink 
Chatting
Going out in the garden when she feels well enough to do so.
appraisal2022.dietaryRequirementInfo:
Helen is physically able to eat independently but needs help cutting food and putting it on her fork/spoon due to her visual impairment.

Helen has a very sweet tooth. Eating cakes and sweet treats is one of her few remaining pleasures.

At the moment Helen is unsettled and this has affected her appetite (her husband was ill and in hospital for a few weeks and recently died). She eats very little and has to be encouraged (with kindness), but when she says she has had enough she means it! It may be better to offer a number of snacks through the day rather than a full meal as she is only eating a few mouthfuls. Also, it is helpful to eat with her as she may eat more if someone is "sharing" with her.
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine:
FOR WAKING NIGHT CARE (7pm to 7am):

Helen goes to bed around 7pm as she is usually very tired by then. She has good nights and bad nights. Sometimes she will sleep for hours at a time, and only get up a few times for the toilet. Other times, she will wake frequently to go to the toilet and may not want to go back to sleep. She uses the ensuite (with help) and also has a commode next to her bed (again, with help to get on and off, and also to remind her what she is doing). 

She can be unsettled at night and a little agitated, but will calm down if someone sits beside her and reassures her. She may want a drink and snack, or to sit in the lounge until she is ready to go back to bed.

Helen has an alarm on her bed that goes off when she gets up, and the receiver is in the carer's room, just across the hallway.  She will need her nightie/pants and bedsheets changing if they are wet. 

FOR DAY CARE (7am to 7pm):

Helen usually gets up between 7.30 and 8am, but may sleep in if she has had a bad night. Again, she can be very confused in the morning and may need (gently) reminding who people are and what she is doing. Her hearing aids must be put in first thing otherwise she will struggle to hear. She will go to the toilet, then be dressed (it's good to put her top on the radiator to warm it up) with a change of pull-up pants. She will usually have a fresh set of clothes every couple of days. While sitting in her bedroom she has a face wash/teeth cleaned (she will brush herself), combs her hair and then walks (with her walking frame) to the kitchen for breakfast around 8.30-9am. 

For breakfast, Helen has an Actimel and up to two slices of toast and jam (breakfast is when she usually eats the most). A list of medications/timings is in the kitchen.

After breakfast, Helen sits in the lounge, snoozing or listening to music. She gets comfort from someone sitting next to her, giving her a cuddle or holding her hand (she used to sit next to her husband on the settee). It's important to sit close to her because otherwise she will not know who is in the room with her (due to her visual impairment) and will get scared.

During the day Helen needs to be offered hot or cold drinks (decaffeinated coffee with milk and one sugar, hot chocolate, squash) and encouraged to drink them. If she wants to walk anywhere with her frame she needs to be accompanied, to remind her where she is going, what she is doing, help her on and off the toilet and clean her up if necessary. 

Helen has a simple lunch (which she calls dinner) around 12.30pm, often something on toast (such as tomatoes, banana or beetroot), a jacket potato (skin removed) with baked beans, or a small portion of fish fingers and chips. Tea is around 5pm, again something simple such as a scone/crumpet/hot cross bun and a cold drink. Always offer a pudding after every meal and biscuits during the day.

After tea, Helen will get ready for bed (toilet/put on nightie and dressing gown/clean pair of pull-up pants). In the evening she can get a little stroppy, and needs someone who is very kind and patient. She cannot see and is often confused, so needs help with everything. She will then go into the lounge for a hot or cold drink until bedtime.
 
Helen doesn't like being washed (she is always cold) and can get distressed. It is a case of washing what is possible (with particular attention to her bottom as she wears pull-ups all day and night, and can get sore), either in the morning before she gets dressed or in the evening before getting ready for bed, depending on her mood. 

Helen hates having her hair washed, and it's a struggle to do that each week.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo:
Helen wears incontinence pants night and day 
Helen needs assistance with using the commode at night. She uses her ensuite toilet with assistance in the day.
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo:
Helen has a pressure alarm in bed, which will alert her carer if she tries to get up at night. The carer's room is just across the hallway. The carer would be expected to go into Helen's room straight away to assist her until she is settled back in bed, but could then return to their own room until they are needed again.

During the day, Helen needs someone with her. If she is sleeping (which she does a lot) the carer can leave the room, but would need to check on her often. Helen needs help with everything, and if she wants to go anywhere in the bungalow she needs to be accompanied, as she will quickly forget where she is going or what it was she wanted to do.
