appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Dad was an Architect and also dabbled in painting. He enjoyed sailing and had several boats over the years. Dad enjoys history and likes watching history programmes on TV. He likes to read the paper. He used to own a horse and enjoyed riding. He likes nature, wildlife.

adDescription:
START DATE: TODAY OR TOMORROW.

Gordon is a lovely gentleman who is due to be discharged from hospital quite urgently. His daughters, Hannah and Lisa, are keen for him to return home with the support of a live-in carer. They also have assistance from a private carer, Anita, who will provide break cover for our carer when needed and help with his knee dressings.

Gordon was admitted to hospital following a fall, which resulted in a cut to his knee. Unfortunately, this has developed into an open wound. District nurses will attend every 1–2 days to manage the dressing. Our carers are not required to carry out any wound care; however, if they notice any concerns, they should contact his daughter Hannah, who will address this.

He has a great sense of humour and loves a good joke. The family are looking for a carer who can confidently support his mobility, help prevent further falls, and assist with personal care.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: mum has hearing aids
mum has 2 hip replacements and 1 knee replacement that effects her mobility.
had one about 20 years ago no impact.

mum is totallly incontinent and wears pads, these need changing on a regular basis - she needs reminding or support to do this. She needs help with showering every day to ensure that she maintains personal hygiene.

Mum has wet/dry eye macular degeneration. She attends hospital for injections into her eye (I think it is her left eye). She has very limited vision in her right eye and is registered paritially sighted. She does have glasses to wear espicially in sunlight. Her limited vision really does impact her everyday life.

Mum has not been formalised diagnosed with Dementia and was given a brief test at the GPs about 2 years ago, but was fine....... I would say rather than dementia she has 'cognitive impairment' a term used by the hosptial when she was last admitted for a UTI - she definitely has short term memory issues. She is not agitated and shows no signs whatso ever of agression, and is normally very placid, easy going and accommodating. She is likely to get stubborn if for example trying to get her out of bed early!

appraisal2022.medicalDeviceInfo: Mum has had 2 hip replacements and 1 knee replacement.  She is also urinary incontinent and wears pads 24 hrs.
appraisal2022.skinIssuesOther: Because she wears pads 24hrs she does need to be reminded to change her pads on a regular basis, and also she needs help with showering and applying barrier cream to prevent soreness and infections.

appraisal2022.recipientLife:
Helen was married for 36 years to Brian, Brian had been her main carer for 5 years and this role had grown as my mums needs had changed and grown. Very sadly Brian was diagnosed with osephegos cancer 3 years and having battled the illness for 3 years died on 17th June 2025 - hence the need for fulltime live in car for mum now. Brian is buried in the local church in the village about 200metres from the house. Brian did not have any children but an estranged sister and brother. Brian was 73 years old when he died)
From mums first marriage of 18 years - she had 4 children Ian aged 64; Mark aged 62 ;Martin Aged 61 and Amanda aged 59. Her 3 sons all live with their wives and children in Southend on Sea, Essex (4 hours drive away) Amanda lives in Reading, Berkshire (2 1/2 hours away). Mum from her children have 10 grandchildren (ages range 23years to 36 years) and 1 great grandson - aged 2.  
All 4 children are in contact with Helen and visit. Amanda visits a minimum of every 3-4 weeks for a couple of days and her sons probably every 2 -3 months. Amanda and Ian are Pats Lasting Power of Attourney and take responsibilty for the overall care, management of the house and finances for Helen. 
Helen was always a VERY active woman - she had a long career in nursing starting as a SRN when she qualified at age 20 years old and working in a range of hospitals in the West Midlands as a nurse, ward sister, nursing officer and then a senior Regional Nursing Officer - part of a regional health team helping to build and equip hospitals. On top of a very rewarding career she was always active : member of canoing teams, orienteering clubs, mountaineering clubs and in later life loved nothing more than being on walking holidays in the mountains, or holidays to her original home area in Norfolk. (She has a brother - William Elmes who lives in norfolk and is in close contact with Helen.)
appraisal2022.recipientNeedToKnow:
Due to mums physical difficulties i think life must be very frustrating for her. She spends most of her time sitting in front of the TV - she loves watching james Bond movies. at the moment.  Mum will come across as very quiet, placid and very easy going and yes she is but underneath lives still the very intelligent, determined and at times playful woman she has always been. 
She does get tired quickly with conversation and people and again i suspect that is due to her short term memory, but when on a good subject or her past will chat for some time. 
Mum still enjoys going out to restuarants, hairdresser, beauticians (to get her nails painted).
appraisal2022.interestsInfo: Due to mobility she spends alot of time watching TV, she may well flick through magazines and loves animals and use to have alot of pets but sadly they have all died. She likes going out especially for meals and enjoys going out to get her hair and nails done on a regular basis. She use to be a very active lady, enjoying walks, cycling, motorbiking, cooking, bridge, going to the gym.
appraisal2022.dietaryRequirementInfo:
Mum does like fish but not to be given any meat at all. 
Since mums stay in hospital recently, her appetite is not as good as it was and we are giving mum fortijuice twice a day. she needs encouragement to eat and drink sometimes. I just dont think she had the appetite she use to have, or the same interest in food.
appraisal2022.dailyRoutine:
11am - pat gets up with help of carer and has a shower every morning (or a bed wash ) as she wears pads at night. She then needs help to get changed into clean clothes.
11.45am transfers from bed in sitting room to chair  with help and is given breakfast (2 weatabix, warm milk with fresh fruit on top and a squirt of honey. A drink of her choice and her morning medicines. (these are in blister packs)
12.30 onwards sits in front of TV. I try and arrange appointments so she has at least 2 a week to get out including a liesure appointment of her choice (normally to a cafe/restuarant/garden centre)
Mum needs to be taken to the toilet every 2 hours to retrain her bladder and get her in the habit of going to the toilet and not using her pads. 
She tends to have lunch 1.30 - 2pm (soup, sandwiches, salad) whatever she wants. If she is out at an appointment then she will want lunch / tea out normally. 
5.30-6pm - she has a cooked tea. She likes fish and vegetables, soup, salad, she does have 1 or 2 ready meals (fish pie) a week but does not live on ready meals (useful if it has been a a busy day. (I have noticed she is increasingly having softer foods to eat (mashed potaoe) she loves fish and chips, potato wedges. I also think she is going for a preference for stronger flavours or salty or sweet. 
Mum also has a range of desserts - she especially likes fresh fruit, trifles, mousses, yogurts, cream cakes, crisps
 8-10pm - mum knows when she wants to go to bed and it is between this time. I would strongly persaude her not to go earlier than 8pm as that will involve her being in bed /pads overnight for over 15 hours... Mum is vulnerable to UTI infections. 
Mum use to get up in the night and go to the toilet and have a pad change - this MUST be reintroduced (advice from doctors and incontinence nursing team). There is a commode in her bedroom.
appraisal2022.continenceInfo: Mum will need to be taken to the toilet every 2 hours and will need support to change pads if they need changing. She can be lazy and wont want to get up to go to the toilet during the day to use the toilet or change pads. , BUT will need reminding to go and change them. Carer should check that she does change them. Because she likes to sleep in bed alot .... goes to bed about 9pm and doesnt get up until 11am, she needs to get up in the night to change her pad.
appraisal2022.attendanceInfo: She is at risk off falling if she is left moving on her own hence carer should ensure mum has everything she needs ie. is sitting in a safe place, has a drink and entertainment before they leave her.

adDescription:
Live-In Carer Needed – Support for Elderly Lady in Rural Village near Oxted 

We are currently seeking a compassionate, proactive live-in carer to support an elderly woman in her own home, located in a peaceful village just outside of Oxted  (approx. 3–4 miles from the town centre).

About the Role:
The client requires gentle assistance with daily living, including:

Dressing and bathing support

Meal preparation and light housekeeping

Encouragement with short-distance walking and mobility

Companionship and meaningful engagement

Ideal Candidate:

Experience supporting older adults with limited mobility

Proactive and attentive, with a warm and engaging personality

Able to work independently in a quiet, rural setting

Must be reliable and respectful of the client's independence and dignity

Family Support:
The client’s family lives in Essex and Reading and is seeking a long-term, live-in carer who can become a trusted presence in their mother's daily life.

If you're a caring individual who takes pride in delivering thoughtful, attentive support — and you're looking for a fulfilling live-in placement — we’d love to hear from you

homeEnvironment2022.homeAccess: Yes the property can be difficult to find as it is a small village and only has a house name.. I say it is past the river Severn and the 3 big house on the left as you go up the hill from the river causeway. Or beside 'The Grange" which is a boutique hotel next door to her.
homeEnvironment2022.homeNeighbourhood:
Beautiful!! She lives in a stunning village on the banks of the river severn with a steam train going through the village and one of the oldest arboreteums in the UK. The village is a bit of a tourist attraction for visitors. There are not many facilities in the village for residents:
There is 1 pub, 1 village shop/post office, 2 teashops and an irregular bus service.
homeEnvironment2022.otherDomesticSupport:
I will order the groceries online each week for home delivery - I will require a shopping list for the carere to prepare.
The carer will need to ensure medications and inconcontinence pads are re-ordered. The carer will need to keep an eye on the fuel level in the house (they just to read the dial and tell me if it gets low). 
The carer will need to turn the TV for mum and also in the winter light and maintain the log burner once a day in the sitting room where mum spends most of her day.

medicalConditions.conditionInfo: Largely just forgetful.

appraisal2022.interestsInfo:
Sadie worked two jobs all her life and brought up three kids. Father passed ten years ago. Worked in the community and spent a lot of time working with charities. Involved with Saint William's Church. Comes from a mining family in the North East. 

Enjoys getting out for a coffee or walks in the park.

adDescription:
We are looking for someone to do Thu-Sun on an ongoing basis with a view to eventually going full time.

Care Needs: Early stages Dementia. Just helping Sadie put together her day effectively and provide companionship. She would also love to start going to church again as well
Driver's License/Car: Not required, but would be a good addition.
Start Date: Mid January - Flexible
Location: London. Easily accessible.
Benefits: free travel and access to e-learning
Night Time Needs: Low. Less than once per night
Breaks: CR okay to be left alone
